# Animation

Animation can play an important role in communicating changing states of your webapp. In this tutorial we'll learn about using `ractive.animate()`.

## Step 1
<div class="tutorial">
  <button Code</button>
</div>

Here, we've got a bar chart showing average temperatures throughout the year. We want there to be a smooth transition when the user changes the city using the dropdown menu.

Find the code that changes the data in the bar chart when the user makes a selection from the dropdown. Change `this.set` to `this.animate`...

...and that's it! We now have a smooth transition between cities â€“ not just the bar height, but the labels and colours as well.

> Ractive.js is efficient about how it handles animations. Even though there are a total of 72 properties being animated each time (height, colour and label text for two bars for each of twelve months), there is a single animation loop which uses `requestAnimationFrame` where possible, and which runs as long as there are one or more sets of animations in progress.
> 
> If a second animation on a keypath were to start before the first had completed, the first would be cancelled.

## Step 2
<div class="tutorial">
  <button data-tutorial="N4IgFiBcoE5SBTAJgcwSAvgGhAZ3gG4CGMABAB5hkC8pAdggO6kAaAsgDIASALjwA4AlBAEcArglw8AFAEoA3AB0YiupRgA6IkiQBRAgjo8OASymGEMaaQDkAGwD22m1lIAzMXQDGPEw7qkcqTAyqqKPDBEPiYGGrgIMiEqdOHhXia+kpCkAFIAygDyAHIa-CTx1jxgZhowkvz+8QAqCOQ8pLJYoSk84fF2CD7IAJJ0SK3ZAAzd4RgK3XNKyeoaDvyG1jYA4rpNLrYA9Gg8ALRSJDzIBzxiPA4wJkR2uNcIALbrkTd1uBoAVrh-DYOktVCt4mM5KCUsliGRItEDKRaAxmIIor4DNIkqpSKQeCRjtkbABiAkwY4ubp4y4fOxES7Esnvfj0y5U5J4hwAI3iMAM2RxAVI4Rs-UGlyQo3G5BsgupIt6VSIYwGMGyHm8vn8gVIJjGrQ6wQVqSVVRqKpMbwZCE24qGSAAwhkAJ77c2-Y6bdKZX7AgDUeoN5CN805itmXXDpv1GQ1T3iJp4GAV2AVSAZRHl4bxuC8TwQGs80R11mIdiNQrx1dIBwOpHEJi8AGtSCqkKQkCYYDwXRp+wqa3VvgEAEykABUpDYDLAWl5ZaeIMHpDTOfc92tPCLWr8AUXFdkxvXeLrpAACjAHCdfPxsowEDY6qQxLh9ShSAADD0aL2yT9Bm+4z4tUuDuMW2oBCcK6nvWRBgUQpA-GIdg8K46KIggpDNnQDiMGByrtB6pBeA4Hy3Aye6dgg6xjLgMG1vWOpVFh5YSKQDhuF+4woHUCBNC66wAfBpAPnYFYiZ+5afgxJhcZUoG--hVEURAHbg2QANq2Dk+w2JlutsLrACCBu6zrrg2ObtgmxbeS6wUutFLrAAiwIALqpgsCggDgPDwAAPF2BB6kg1CKCA5LHOHAB8-sHEH0dhHQ-t5g8-DtCYofh+tbIIOH+KCQgYcR60PAHAimJ5yAic9IHMQkfSuC4NQNjrZYm0-DYNepD0eL+wAhCcs1Gdoh3thx6d7mBQ-d+0pB18HXiN83Ngj+MMBd2Ec992Ao7R0btlEGgpALWA3Udo4zBt18W1x7vs9bzWA9D6QuCMBkXhn9yCQPoY9mOc5ceekDKeWMu0Gej9qwLwbvBFekQuzXl4qdfgm9e4WX9vSb+dho5FUdPPfU-BbgF3WC3eBfhgR0FVkXGwwBgCqQQPxQuGAMDAjYtQrwDk3yvmBJ-QYzZkCxwOJghys84oYKIFgnBmV8F0EIURQupDtDkPoFQlutD6GMPWMw1hTwJAt2AR5LyPAu5x2EdgyBfd44xAfmgvug9ZpICvPwJAeEAgHToGIGaJxRFQPtO0NhajgB+JGMGbRPiay0JJAgKIZ8fQmCyHqZhFj0FrEgkzOweiaHABMGE2hlCDrMLjqkvc4Tqy0IONEz+STbHzwOH4nxccE5b0gc-Wau1P4XC8Q0oOMCm4t25CQE4HSeyoPCBE4AJJ35VFfg5CUyBnS9mqT3MZ6D7GkCCuOeIg1cCuH8FhNw9xSCVLPorIwZ8IE1LxJE45pBTlVHVoklMlyoE9KXrA-pgykFiBQa-XsAwW7vyQFUQUwB1mo1rLcpWYBfgDDoCgaZzCACk8hRm9GeU-NZRBD7H1PviFk7dvhYQuSsuKfdXnLw+TAE4p1LhkFxbQwIuLo60EmEeAA-CKEADQ3yV3ztkcODAUCUQMPnbRvyXT-NXsZRa25gigrzAWaQp8jxIpRaU0l89yXvJsAMql+oGAb3FZKgZLYvljCGSdeqDLqqWqVSYRaKqMBqsadY5JGqU5lDoNHBlByYBbjtQ61cGA464E9eq9BViCA2OWdvUlrS2zYqwpfPFHwCVbS6W69BWq+k6sGTSw6yaGXSGTcy0grLSAcvDtyjIMQq6kH5SAQVwq61iqkBK6hXkZUgtfvmAYxa8KOuRaijVT9s0r11ScfVlhgRtuNVEZsZqkAWrqt2m1dV+2 snYcOQH73WNB-bABM29ARAe3ZB-dmrT2IcIs+zNsLAw3Baox+Ee5Rh9vNnawAdk6+EDjDATiw+bWF5j67gzraJ6oH6GLUPqICqV+zfB2LZBOOuTr5210Qv4IN8ruSaejfB+9yHTPUoaEytbm3NuAAsS2xfQ8vuzBk2RWc8DC5cNoJwng+roNkcRRhLCy562umtZAqeG+G7Tx7dWzeM7h0txHMXsZJX4IT3bBP9sxbx5YRLBPQ8k+rU9zQt2kSA9V3cN42R1zw7O79kvXKND9o7qV1r2RUr1663LtdG7I9eej3dk3HcGdQ++5fJ3E-MfZ+x7n47+fTs97D03ywpQh9ImL9augtqVcL-Zaw8CteM9cxP9jDn4X9+oYQGzszJ+asV1ICSG3YW88H59W59PIYH+Tmf9b1-V+HeZy9+3Uj+f+mUABauNe4uDexO4epeLeCA8qbeW+Uuu+leV+h+fy5+p+IY64GeAB8W+eHud+3+oBv+L+WeRB7+jWX+IC5BT+lBM+1BBeUBpB9BHGFB-">Fix Code</button>
</div>

That's good, but it looks a bit... robotic. That's because the animation is following a linear path. We can make the whole thing look much slicker with an _easing function_. Find the existing animation code and update it:

```js
this.animate( 'selectedCity', cities[ index ], {
  easing: 'easeOut'
});
```

Execute this code, then try changing the city via the drop-down.

> Ractive.js has four easing functions built in â€“ `linear` (the default), `easeIn`, `easeOut` and `easeInOut`. I personally find `easeOut` and `easeInOut` meet 95% of my needs.
> 
> However you can add more easing functions to `Ractive.easing`, and they will become globally available. Here's an elastic easing function, for example:
> 
    Ractive.easing.elastic = function( pos ) {
      return -1 * Math.pow(4,-8*pos) * Math.sin((pos*6-1)*(2*Math.PI)/2) + 1;
    };
>
> This was taken from [danro's easing.js](https://github.com/danro/easing-js/blob/master/easing.js), which contains just about every easing function you could imagine. Or you could create your own â€“ all it is is a function that takes an x value between 0 (animation start) and 1 (animation end) and returns a y value (usually between 0 and 1, but sometimes just outside as in the `elastic` example).
>
> As an alternative to making easing functions globally available, you can pass a function in as the `easing` parameter rather than a string.

## Step 3

  <button data-run="true" Code</button>
</div>

Alongside `easing`, there are several other options you can pass in when creating an animation:

```js
this.animate( 'selectedCity', cities[ index ], {
  easing: 'easeOut',
  duration: 300, // in milliseconds - default 400
  step: function ( t, value ) {
    // function that will be called immediately after
    // each step of the animation loop.
    //
    // `t` is a value between 0 (start) and 1 (end),
    // as determined by the easing function.
    //
    // `value` is the intermediate value
  }
}).then( function () {
  // .animate() returns a promise that fulfils
  // when the animation completes
});
```

Try using `ractive.animate()` to cycle the bar chart through a loop â€“ each city's data is displayed for a couple of seconds before transitioning to the next one. To make it simple, the `<select>` has been removed. If you get stuck, use the 'Fix Code' button to see one possible solution.

> You can animate between numerical properties, and arrays or objects that contain numerical properties (nested however deep â€“ though be aware that Ractive.js doesn't check for cyclical data structures which will cause infinite loops!).
> 
> Strings, such as the city's `name` in this example, are ignored, or rather set immediately on the first animation tick. (Future versions may include clever string interpolators Ã  la [D3](http://d3js.org/).)
